title: 115_s1194
content: The "Medical Nutrition Equity Act of 2017" acknowledges the necessity of specialized food for managing digestive and metabolic disorders. Despite its importance, the high cost and lack of insurance coverage create financial hardships for many families. This can lead to adverse health effects and even death for patients unable to afford medically necessary food. The "Medical Nutrition Equity Act of 2017" aims to provide coverage for medically necessary food and vitamins for digestive and inherited metabolic disorders under federal health programs and private health insurance. The "Medical Nutrition Equity Act of 2017" expands coverage under the Medicare program to include medically necessary food and related supplies for certain health conditions. The Security Act is amended to include a new subsection. "Medically Necessary Food" The term 'medically necessary food' refers to specially formulated products prescribed by a healthcare professional for individuals with dietary management needs due to a covered disease or condition. These products are intended for individuals with limited capacity to ingest, digest, or absorb nutrients. The term 'medically necessary food' refers to specially formulated products prescribed by a healthcare professional for individuals with limited capacity to ingest, digest, absorb, or metabolize food or nutrients. These products are intended for individuals with special medically determined nutrient requirements that cannot be met by modifying their normal diet alone. They are used under medical supervision, including in a home setting, for individuals requiring ongoing medical care and instructions on the use of the food. The term 'medically necessary food' refers to specially formulated products prescribed by a healthcare professional for individuals with limited capacity to ingest, digest, absorb, or metabolize food or nutrients. These products are intended for individuals with special medically determined nutrient requirements that cannot be met by modifying their normal diet alone. They are used under medical supervision, including in a home setting, for individuals requiring ongoing medical care and instructions on the use of the food. The covered diseases or conditions for such foods include inherited metabolic disorders and other specified conditions determined appropriate by the Secretary. Newborns and children with N-acetyl glutamate synthase deficiency, ornithine transcarbamlyase deficiency, carbamoyl phosphate synthestase deficiency, inherited disorders of mitochondrial functioning, malabsorption conditions such as short bowel syndrome and chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction, malabsorption due to liver or pancreatic disease, and allergies to food proteins. Allergies to food proteins, including Immunoglobulin E and non-Immunoglobulin E-mediated allergies, food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome, eosinophilic disorders, inflammatory or immune mediated conditions of the alimentary tract such as inflammatory bowel disease and nonresponsive gastroesophageal reflux disease, and any other appropriate diseases or conditions determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may determine other appropriate diseases or conditions. A low protein modified food product has less than one gram of protein per serving. Payment for medically necessary food will be 80% of the lesser of the actual charge or the fee schedule amount. The amendments made by this subsection apply to items and services provided one year after the enactment of the Act. Medically necessary vitamins are now included as a covered part D drug under the Social Security Act. The amendments include coverage for medically necessary vitamins used for managing a covered disease or condition under the Medicaid Program, with an effective date one year after the enactment of the Act. The Medicaid Program will now cover medically necessary food, medical equipment, supplies, and vitamins for managing covered diseases or conditions as prescribed by a healthcare provider. The Medicaid Program will cover medically necessary food, medical equipment, supplies, and vitamins prescribed by a qualified healthcare professional. Amendments have been made to expand coverage and exceptions. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act, with an exception for State plans requiring legislation to meet additional requirements. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act, with an exception for State plans requiring legislation to meet additional requirements related to coverage under CHIP, including medically necessary food assistance for targeted low-income children. The amendments include coverage of medically necessary food, equipment, supplies, and vitamins for targeted low-income children under the plan. A conforming amendment to the Social Security Act is also made. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act, with an exception for State child health plans that require additional legislation to meet the new requirements. The State child health plan is not required to meet additional requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's session following the enactment of the Act. TRICARE program's coverage of diseases and conditions is modified by striking a certain subparagraph. The text chunk discusses amendments to coverage under the FEHBP, including the requirement for carriers to provide coverage for medically necessary food, equipment, supplies, and vitamins. The amendment made under section 1860D-2(e)(1)(C) of the Social Security Act applies to contract years starting one year after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Subpart II of part A of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include coverage under private health insurance. Coverage of medically necessary food, vitamins, and related supplies is mandated for health insurance plans, with the amendment applying to plan years starting one year after the enactment of the Act.
